Key Laboratory for Special Functional Materials of Ministry of Education and School of Materials Science and Engineering Henan University Kaifeng 475004 Henan China Graphical abstract First-principles calculations indicate that the heteronuclear FeCo or NiCo dimers anchored graphdiyne have a comparable and even better catalytic activity towards nitrogen reduction reaction than their homonuclear counterparts, and furthermore, they have an obviously enhanced catalytic selectivity than the homonuclear counterparts. Developing efficient electrocatalysts for nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is crucial to replace the both energy–intensive and environment–malignant Haber–Bosch process. Here using density functional theory calculations, we systematically studied the potential of the heteronuclear 3d transition metal dimers anchored graphdiyne monolayers (FeM@ and NiM@GDY, M = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) as efficient NRR catalysts. Among all the studied double–atom catalysts (DACs), FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY are the most promising with excellent NRR catalytic activity, high ability to suppress the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and good stability. For both FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY, NRR prefers to the distal pathway with the calculated onset potentials of −0.44 and −0.36 V, respectively, which are comparable and even better than their homonuclear counterparts. Moreover, FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY have higher ability to suppress HER than Fe2@ and Co2@GDY, which may result from the modulated d state electronic structure due to the synergy effect of the heteronuclear atoms in the DACs. Our work not only suggests that FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY hold great promises as efficient, low–cost, and stable DACs for NRR, but also further provides a strategy, i.e. alloying the atomic metal catalysts, to improve the NRR catalytic activity and/or selectivity. Keywords Nitrogen reduction reaction Graphdiyne Double-atom catalyst First Principles calculation 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) plays an extremely important role in the modern agriculture and chemical industry [1,2]. Currently, industrial productions of NH3 mainly rely on the Haber-Bosch processes on the ion-based catalysts (N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3) proposed one century ago. The process operates under extremely harsh conditions (400–600 ℃ and 50–300 atm), and are both significantly energy-intensive and environment-malignant, responsible for ~ 2% global annual energy consumption and ~ 3% CO2 global emission [3–5]. Inspired by the biological nitrogen fixation occurring under mild conditions, the electrocatalysis nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) has gained significant and increasing attentions, due to its economically and environmentally friendly. For NRR, it is crucial to develop stable and efficient electrocatalysts due to the extreme inertness of the N2 molecule, however which is still a great challenge currently [6–10]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) with the isolated metal/nonmetal atom anchored on solid supports [11,12] have received extensive research attentions in the various electrocatalysis fields, such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), CO2 reduction reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [13–18]. The unique electronic structure and the homogeneity in the active sites of SACs have been proven to be responsible for the high catalytic activity and selectivity, and the maximum atom–utilization enables reasonable use of metal resources and achieves atomic economy. The SACs based on the two–dimensional (2D) materials have been emphasized [19]. Especially, in recent few years, there are great efforts to explore the design and application of SACs based on 2D materials for NRR [20–32]. For example, combining experiments and first–principle calculations based on the density functional theory (DFT), it is shown that the Ru SACs based on the N-doped carbon [20], the Au [22], or Ru [24] SACs based on g–C3N4, and the Mo SACs [29] based on graphdiyne (denoted as Mo@GDY) exhibit high NRR catalytic activity and selectivity against the competing HER. With the experimental researches, there are also lots of theoretical efforts devoted to NRR catalyzed by the SACs, which will play an important role in advancing the NRR catalysis [33–47]. For example, the Co SACs anchored on the graphene edges have been suggested as an available catalyst for NRR [47], which may be further optimized by the strain engineering [48]. As extended family members of SACs, double-atom catalysts (DACs) have very recently emerged as the research focus, where metal dimers are supported on or embedded into an appropriate substrate [49–58]. For example, experimentally Li et al., through the “precursor–preselected” strategy, have synthesized the stable Fe2 dimers embedded into the pore of the C3N4 supports, which exhibit superior catalytic performance for the epoxidation of trans–stilbene to trans–stilbene oxide [49]. Furthermore, interestingly besides homonuclear DACs, heteronuclear DACs have also been synthesized very recently. Zhang et al. using atomic layer deposition (ALD) technology synthesized the PtRu dimers supported on the N–doped carbon nanotube (NCNT), which exhibit much higher HER activity and excellent stability than the commercial Pt/C catalysts [50]. Assisted with metal–organic frameworks, FeCo [51,52] and NiFe [53] dimers supported on the N–doped carbon supports have been realized, which exhibit excellent performances for ORR [51,52] and CO2 reduction reaction [53], respectively. Theoretically, DACs have also gained a lot of attentions [59–66]. Interestingly, it is shown that in some cases the DACs have higher catalytic performance than the SACs counterparts. Zhang et al. and Chen et al., respectively, revealed that Mo2 [59] and Mn2 [60] DACs based on the C2N monolayers are the best towards NRR among a series of SACs and DACs. Moreover, Li et al. showed that the heteronuclear DACs (FeCu supported on C2N) even have better CO catalytic activity and higher ability to resist CO poisoning than their homonuclear counterparts [61]. Zhao et al. revealed a selective C–C coupling for CO2 reduction by spatially confined transition metal (TM) dimers into various nitrogenated holey carbon monolayers [66]. The GDY monolayer is one of the most important carbon allotropes with single–atom thickness [67]. Its unique structural, physical, and chemical properties enable GDY having various potential applications in catalysis, rechargeable batteries, electronics, and so on [68–73]. Especially, the uniformly distributed subnano–scale pore and its surrounding sp–hybridized carbon atoms make GDY appropriate support to firmly anchor the atomic metal catalysts with one or several TM atoms [29,74–85]. Experimentally, SACs Fe@GDY [76,78], Ni@GDY [76], Pd@GDY [82], and Mo@GDY [29] have been synthesized for some important electrochemical reactions, such as HER (Fe@GDY [76] and Pd@GDY [82]), ORR (Fe@GDY [78]), and NRR (Mo@GDY [29]). Theoretically, the potentials of the SACs based on GDY have been investigated for CO oxidation [77], water splitting, ORR [75], and NRR [84]. Moreover, Xing et al. have studied the Ru x Os3- x trimers anchored GDY monolayers for semihydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene, all of which exhibit robust stability, and high activity and selectivity [81]. Du et al. have investigated the CO2 reduction reaction on the small Fe clusters supported on GDY [86]. We have studied the Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni monomers, and the corresponding homonuclear dimers and trimers anchored GDY monolayers for NRR, and further showed that the proposed DACs own much higher NRR activity than the other atomic metal catalysts [85]. As mentioned above, the DACs with heteronuclear metal dimers have been synthesized [50–53] and may perform better than their homonuclear counterparts as revealed in the CO oxidation reaction [61]. Considering that Fe@ and Ni@GDY have been synthesized [76], in this work based on DFT calculations, we investigated the heteronuclear FeM and NiM (M = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) dimers anchored GDY monolayers (denoted as FeM@GDY and NiM@GDY, respectively) as DACs for NRR. Our theoretical results show that, for FeM@ and NiM@GDY DACs, FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY have the highest catalytic activity, respectively, in terms of the calculated onset potential (U Onset), which are comparable or even better than their homonuclear counterparts. More importantly, FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY exhibit much higher selectivity towards NRR against HER than Fe2@ and Co2@GDY homonuclear DACs, which were predicted to have high NRR activity [85]. Our findings not only propose two low–cost and efficient electrocatalysts for NRR, but also suggest that alloying may be a promising strategy to improve the catalytic activity and/or selectivity of the atomic metal catalysts supported on an appropriate support. 2 Computational details All spin–polarized total energy and electronic structure calculations were performed by using DFT implemented in Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [87,88]. The interactions between electrons and ion–cores are treated by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [89], and the exchange–correlation interactions are described by the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [90]. To account for the weak dispersion interactions between the adsorbates and the supports, DFT + D3 methods are used [91]. The cutoff energy for the plane-wave basis set is taken as 450 eV. The convergence tolerances for the total energy and the force for structural optimizations are 10−5 eV and 0.02 eVÅ−1, respectively. A (2 × 2) GDY monolayer supercell with a ~18 Å vacuum layer has been used as the support to simulate the adsorption and reaction. For such supercell, 3 × 3 × 1 and 7 × 7 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grids [92] are used for the structural optimization and the calculation of densities of states (DOS), respectively. In addition, the kinetic and the thermal stabilities of the proposed catalysts are evaluated by the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI–NEB) [93] and the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations [94], respectively. The binding energy (E b) for the metal atoms or the adsorption energy (E ad) for the reaction intermediates are defined as E b/E ad = E tot – E sup – E, in which E, E sup, and E tot represent the total energies of the isolated atom or molecule, the clean support, and the support with the adsorbates, respectively. The calculations of the Gibbs free–energy change (ΔG) for each elemental step have adopted the computational hydrogen electrode model (CHE) proposed by Nørskov and co–workers [95,96], which can be obtained by the following equation ΔG = ΔE + ΔE ZPE − TΔS + eU + ΔG pH In this equation, ΔE is the adsorption energy of the intermediates defined above, and ΔE ZPE and TΔS (see Tables S1, S2, and S5 of the Supporting Information (SI)) are the contribution of the zero–point energies and entropies to ΔG, respectively, both of which are obtained by the vibrational frequencies. The vibrational frequencies for the free molecules are taken from the NIST databases [97], while those of the intermediates were calculated. T is temperature, which is set as 298.15 K, and e and U are the number of electrons transferred and the electrode potential applied, respectively. ΔG pH is the free energy correction due to pH and calculated by k B T × ln10 × pH, where k B is the Boltzmann constant and pH = 0 is assumed in acidic medium in this work. U Onset is defined as U Onset = − ΔG max/e, where G max is the ΔG of the potential–determining step (PDS). The solvation effects have not been included as previous works [41,43], due to that the stabilization of the intermediates induced by the solvation in NRR is small (within 0.1 eV) [98]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stabilities of FeM@ and NiM@GDY Firstly, we studied the atomic and electronic structures of the pristine GDY monolayer. As shown in Fig. S1, the calculated lattice parameter is 9.45 Å and the band gap of the GDY monolayer unit cell is 0.49 eV, in line with the previous results [99]. Previous studies further showed that TM single atoms on GDY prefer to locate at the corner site of the acetylenic ring surrounded by the sp–hybridized C atoms (H1 site in Fig. S1(a)) [75,76,78,85]. Our calculations predicted that the binding energies for the Fe and Ni single atoms at H1 sites are −3.32 and −4.01 eV, respectively [85]. Although both values are more positive than their corresponding bulk cohesive energies (−4.28 and −4.44 eV, respectively, for Fe and Ni), the high diffusion energy barriers (>2 eV) indicate that the clustering of Fe or Ni atoms can be kinetically prevented and Fe or Ni can exist in the form of single atoms on GDY [85], which are in good agreement with the experiment findings on the Fe@ and Ni@GDY SACs [76,78]. Very recently, Zhang et al. using a two–step ALD process synthesized the PtRu heteronuclear DACs based on the NCNTs [50]. They firstly achieved the Pt SACs on the NCNTs by ALD processing with the precursors containing Pt single atoms, and then synthesized the PtRu DACs by ALD processing with the precursors containing Ru single atoms based on the already synthesized Pt SACs. It is expected that the proposed FeM@ and NiM@GDY DACs may also be realized by the similar two–step ALD process. Considering the definite existence of Fe@ and Ni@GDY revealed by experiments and calculations [75,76,78,85], we may firstly synthesize Fe@ or Ni@GDY by the first ALD processing, and then deposit the second TM atom on these substrates by the second ALD processing to achieve FeM@ or NiM@GDY DACs. Therefore, to construct FeM@ or NiM@GDY, the second TM atoms (Ti ~ Cu) have been placed at the H1 sites neighboring the already deposited Fe or Ni single atoms. The obtained most stable configurations of NiCo@GDY are shown in Fig. 1 (a). Both Ni and Co atoms are within the atomic plane of the GDY monolayer, and almost all the FeM@ and NiM@GDY systems share this structural characteristic. We studied the binding strengths of the Ti ~ Cu atoms on the Fe@ and Ni@DGY substrates, and further compared the binding energies for the Fe@ or Ni@GDY substrates with those for the pristine GDY substrate. The calculated binding energies for the Fe@GDY, Ni@GDY, and pristine GDY substrates are shown in Table S3, and the comparison results in Fig. 1(b). We can see that for all the substrates the Ti ~ Cu atoms have significantly negative binding energies, indicating that strong chemical bonds (or chemisorptions) have been developed between Ti ~ Cu atoms and the substrates. This can be verified by the short bond lengths between the TM atoms and its neighboring TM or C atoms together with the large charge transfer from the TM atoms to the substrates (Table S4). More importantly, for all the cases, the binding energies are more negative for the Fe@ and Ni@GDY substrates than those for the pristine GDY substrate, suggesting that Ti ~ Cu atoms bind more strongly at the H1 sites neighboring the Fe or Ni single atoms than the pristine H1 sites. For example, the binding energies for Co on Fe@ and Ni@GDY are −4.56 and −4.21 eV, respectively, while that on the pristine GDY substrate is −3.84 eV (Table S3). In addition, previous studies showed that the 3d TM atoms from Ti to Cu can exist in the form of single atoms on the pristine GDY monolayer [75]. Therefore, the strong chemisorption characters and enhanced binding strengths suggest that on the Fe@ or Ni@GDY substrate the deposited Ti ~ Cu atoms can be selectively attached at the H1 sites neighboring the Fe or Ni single atoms (rather than the pristine H1 sites) and they will not suffer from the clustering problem. In addition, we also studied the adsorption configurations with the second TM atoms sitting above the deposited Fe (for Fe@GDY) or Ni atoms (for Ni@GDY). It is found that, as shown in Table S3, for all the cases these kinds of configurations are much less stable than the above discussed ones. Therefore, the second TM atoms cannot directly form alloy with the already deposited Fe or Ni single atoms. It is noted that from Table S4 for all the DACs (except NiCu@GDY) there are large spin magnetic moments on the deposited TM atoms, which may make these DACs have high NRR catalytic activities as suggested by previous studies [33,34]. The effect of the spin magnetic moment on the NRR results from the underlying mechanism for N2 adsorption and activation on the TM based NRR catalysts. Efficient NRR catalysts based on TM should be able to effectively bind and activate N2 molecule, which can be ascribed to their advantageous combination of occupied and empty d orbitals [5]. On the one hand, TM active centers need to have empty d orbitals to accept the lone–pair electrons of N2. On the other hand, the TM active centers should have separate d electrons that can be donated into the antibonding orbital of N2 to weaken the N–N bond. Therefore, the electron “acceptance–donation” is the nature of the interaction between the TM and N2, where the simultaneous existence of the empty and occupied d orbitals plays the key role. The existence of spin magnetic moments on the TM atoms means that there are certain orbitals occupied by the unpaired electrons, and thus in this case there must be empty and occupied d orbitals simultaneously, for the N2 activation. In addition, it is noted that although the existence of the spin magnetic moments on the TM atoms may make TM based catalysts highly active for NRR, the quantitative correlation between the spin magnetic moments and the catalytic activities has not been observed in the previous and present works. For example, NiCo@ and FeCo@GDY have similar NRR catalytic activities as shown below, while FeCo@GDY (~3 μB) owns much larger spin magnetic moments than NiCo@GDY (~1 μB). 3.2 Screening FeM@ and NiM@GDY as NRR catalysts Previous studies showed that an efficient NRR catalyst should be able to efficiently capture N2 molecule, selectively stabilize *NNH species, and destabilize *NH2 species [34,39]. According to these criteria, the adsorption of N2 molecules on the FeM@ and NiM@GDY catalysts has been studied and the ΔG values for N2 adsorption has been adopted as the indicator for N2 capture. For N2 adsorption, both the end–on (N2 α) and side–on (N2 β) configurations have been considered, and the optimized configurations are shown in Fig. S2 with the calculated ΔG values, which are also tabulated in Table S6 together with the ΔG values for the formation of *NNH and the protonation of *NH2 to *NH3. From Fig. 2 (a) and Fig. S2, we can see that except FeTi@, FeV, and NiTi@GDY, N2 α configuration is more stable than N2 β configuration on all the catalysts. For all the favorable adsorption configurations, although the adsorption of N2 on NiCr@ and NiMn@GDY catalysts is weak with the ΔG values of −0.01 and −0.06 eV, respectively, it is rather strong for all the other catalysts with ΔG values ranging from −0.21 to −0.86 eV, suggesting that these catalysts can effectively capture N2 molecules. Here, we provide an explanation why different catalysts prefer different N2 adsorption configurations based on the integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) [100] and the redefinition of the adsorption energy (E ad = E int + E dist). As discussed in Note 1 of SI, ICOHP quantitatively reflects the strength of the chemical bond. E dist quantifies the overall effect of the structural change upon the adsorption, and E int should be able to reflect the strength of the chemical bond between the adsorbed N2 and the support. With these, we could conclude that, it is the competition between the chemical bonding interaction and the structural distortion effect that determines the energetically favorable adsorption configuration for an individual catalyst. For the FeTi@, FeV@, and NiTi@GDY catalysts, such competition leads to that the N2 β are more stable than the N2 α configurations, while due to the large structural distortion of the N2 β configuration, N2 adsorption prefers the N2 α configuration for the other catalysts. The full discussion on this can be found in Note 1 of SI. Then we studied the protonation of *N2 to form *NNH and the protonation of *NH2 to form *NH3. We can see that in Fig. 2(b) and Table S6 for FeM@GDY, FeTi/V@GDY and FeCu@GDY favor the formation of *NNH (ΔG = 0.10 eV) and the protonation of *NH2 (ΔG = 0.10 eV), respectively. However, FeTi@ and FeV@GDY have high ΔG values of 0.62 and 0.48 eV, respectively, for the protonation of *NH2, and FeCu@GDY does not favor the formation of *NNH with a ΔG value of 0.79 eV. Finally, it is noted that FeCo@GDY can balance the formation of *NNH and the protonation of *NH2 with the ΔG values of 0.34 and 0.44 eV, respectively, and thus may serve as an eligible NRR catalyst. Similar analysis finds that, for the NiM@GDY catalysts, NiCo@GDY catalysts are the most promising ones with the ΔG values of 0.36 and 0.25 eV, respectively, for the formation of *NNH and the protonation of *NH2. In the following we will focus on FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY catalysts for NRR. 3.3 NRR on FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY catalysts Firstly, the mechanisms for N2 adsorption on FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY are discussed. As shown in Fig. 3, N2 adsorption on FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY prefer to adopt the N2 α configuration with the ΔG values of ~ -0.4 eV. In both configurations, N2 molecules tend to bind with the Co atoms with the Co–N bond lengths of ~ 1.8 Å, and upon adsorption the N–N bonds are elongated from 1.11 Å in the isolated N2 molecule to 1.13 Å, suggesting that N2 molecules are moderately activated. To explore the adsorption mechanism, we calculated the charge density differences of FeCo–N2 α and NiCo–N2 α systems (Fig. 3 ), for which significant charge redistribution can be observed. Bader charge analysis [101] shows that there is large number of electrons transferred from the substrate to the N2 molecule (0.26 and 0.22 e, respectively, for FeCo–N2 α and NiCo–N2 α). However, interestingly, charge density differences show that the charge transfer adopts the two-way mode, i.e., both charge accumulation and depletion can be seen on the adsorbed N2 and the embedded TM atoms. Furthermore, from Fig. 3(a) and (c) the charge accumulation on the adsorbed N2 should mainly occupy the anti-bonding orbitals, which leads to the weakening of the N–N bond. Therefore, the chemisorption of N2 on FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY can be ascribed to the so–called electron “acceptance–donation” mechanism, as proposed previously [5]. As shown in Fig. S2, for both FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY, N2 energetically highly prefer to the N2 α configurations with the ΔG differences about 0.3 eV compared with the N2 β configurations. Therefore, to estimate the NRR activity of FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY, we have systematically explored two reaction pathways, including distal and alternating mechanisms, according to previous studies [38,39]. For NRR, there are six proton–electron pair (H++e−) transfer reactions, and the capture of N2 and the desorption of NH3. For the distal mechanism, firstly the proton-electron pairs consecutively attack the distal N atom producing the first NH3 molecule, and then another N atom to form the second NH3 molecule. For the alternating mechanism, the proton–electron pairs alternately attack the two N atoms producing the first NH3 molecule at the fifth proton–electron pair transfer reaction. The free energy diagrams of the distal and alternating pathways with the optimized structures of the reaction intermediates for the FeCo@GDY catalyst are shown in Figs. 4 and S3, respectively, and the relevant structural parameters in Table S7. Our calculations show that for both the distal and alternating pathways the first protonation step, i.e. *N–N + H+ + e− → *N–NH, requires a free energy input of only 0.34 eV, and simultaneously the N–N bond is elongated to 1.22 Å. The difference between the two reaction pathways come from the second protonation step. For the distal pathway, it releases an energy of 0.09 eV, while for the alternating pathway an energy input of 0.86 eV is needed, which is the PDS of the alternating pathway and gives an U Onset of −0.86 V. Therefore, the NRR on FeCo@GDY highly prefer to the distal pathway. Along the distal pathway, the next three protonation steps are exothermic by 0.06, 0.79, and 0.79 eV, respectively. The PDS is the last protonation step with a free energy uphill of 0.44 eV, and thus the U Onset is −0.44 V for the NRR on the FeCo@GDY catalyst along the distal pathway. Finally, the ΔG value for the desorption of NH3 is 0.65 eV, indicating that the produced NH3 can be easily removed, and thus the FeCo@GDY catalyst can be easily recovered under the experimental conditions. Now we turn to the discussion on the NRR on the NiCo@GDY catalyst, for which the free energy diagrams are shown in Figs. 5 and S4, and the relevant structural parameters in Table S8. Similar to the case of FeCo@GDY, the NRR on NiCo@GDY also prefers to adopt the distal pathway. The first protonation step needs a small energy input of 0.36 eV, while the ΔG values for the second protonation steps are 0.18 and 0.85 eV, respectively, for the distal (Fig. 5 ) and alternating (Fig. S4) pathways. Then the ΔG values along the distal pathway for the next four protonation steps are 0.21, −1.03, −0.92, and 0.26 eV, respectively. Therefore, the PDS for the NRR on NiCo@GDY is the first protonation step with the free energy uphill of 0.36 eV giving an U Onset of −0.36 V. In addition, the ΔG value for the desorption of NH3 on NiCo@GDY is also small (0.72 eV), indicating an easy recovery of the catalyst. To evaluate the catalytic activity of FeCo@GDY (U Onset = −0.44 V) and NiCo@GDY (U Onset = −0.36 V), we compared the calculated U Onset values with those of the atomic metal catalysts for NRR proposed very recently. It is expected that FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY have comparable or better catalytic activities than some of these proposed catalysts in terms of the calculated U Onset, such as the Mo–embedded BN monolayer (−0.35 V) [34], the W–anchored C3N4 (−0.35 V) [38], the Ru–anchored B sheet (−0.42 V) [40], the Mo–embedded BCN monolayer (−0.58 V) [46], and the Mo dimer–anchored C2N (−0.41 V) [59]. Furthermore, compared with their homonuclear counterparts, FeCo@GDY exhibits a comparable catalytic activity to Fe2@GDY (U Onset = −0.39 V) and Co2@GDY (U Onset = −0.43 V), and even NiCo@GDY has a higher catalytic activity than Co2@GDY (U Onset = −0.43 V) and Ni2@GDY (U Onset = −0.92 V) [85]. An efficient NRR catalyst should have high selectivity against the competing HER. Within the framework of the CHE model, the free energy changes for the first step (N2 and H adsorption, respectively, for NRR and HER) have been often considered as the descriptor to evaluate the reaction selectivity, and the reactions with lower ΔG values are assumed to be more selective [35,39]. As shown in Figs. 6 and S5, the ΔG differences between N2 and H adsorption on FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY are −0.09 and −0.21 eV, respectively, while those on Fe2@, Co2@, and Ni2@GDY are 0.16, −0.02, −0.22 eV, respectively. These results suggest that FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY have higher ability to suppress HER than Fe2@ and Co2@GDY. Furthermore, it is observed that the ΔG value for H on FeCo@GDY (−0.33 eV) is more positive than that on Fe2@GDY (−0.48 eV) and Co2@GDY (−0.48 eV), and the ΔG value for H on NiCo@GDY (−0.19 eV) is also more positive than that on Ni2@GDY (−0.24 eV) and Co2@GDY (−0.48 eV). Although the changes in the adsorption strengths of N2 are also observed, they are not significant compared with H adsorption. Therefore, the suppressed H adsorption should play a major role for the enhanced NRR selectivity. To explore the possible mechanism, we have studied the electronic structures of NiCo@, FeCo@GDY, and their homonuclear counterparts, for which the calculated local DOS (LDOS) projected on the d orbitals of the embedded TM atoms are shown in Fig. S6. Based on the LDOS, we have further studied their d-band centers (Fig. 7 and Table S9) for the whole energy range (−∞ to +∞) [102]. It is found that the d–band centers of the Co atom in FeCo@GDY are comparable with those of the Co atoms in Co2@GDY. However, the d-band centers of both the spin–up and spin–down states of the Fe atom in FeCo@GDY are lower than the corresponding d–band centers of the Fe atoms in Fe2@GDY, which should be qualitatively responsible for the decreased adsorption strength for H on FeCo@GDY compared with Fe2@ and Co2@GDY. For NiCo@GDY, similar to FeCo@GDY, the downshift of the d–band centers of the Ni atom in NiCo@GDY compared with those in Ni2@GDY should be responsible for the decreased H adsorption strength. In addition, the d–band centers below the Fermi level (Ef), from −2 eV to Ef, and the highest peak position of the LDOS have been studied (Table S9) [103]. However, there is no correlation observed between these parameters with the changed H adsorption behavior. We also tried to explore the correlation between the d–band center and the binding strength of N2 on Fe2@ and FeCo@GDY. From Fig. S5, on FeCo@GDY, N2 is bonded with the Co atom, while it is bonded with the Fe2 atom on Fe2@GDY. Moreover, N2 binding on FeCo@GDY is stronger than that on Fe2@GDY by ~0.1 eV. We examined the d–band centers of the Co atom in FeCo@GDY and the Fe2 atom in Fe2@GDY. From Table S9, the d–band center of the spin–down state of the Co atom is lower than that of the Fe2 atom. However, the higher d–band center of the spin-up state of the Co atom (−1.47 eV) compared with the Fe2 atom (−1.98 eV) may be responsible for the stronger adsorption of N2 on FeCo@GDY compared with Fe2@GDY. According to the above results, FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY are promising NRR electrocatalysts with high activity and high ability to suppress the competing HER. Furthermore, high electrical conductivity is beneficial for the charge transfer of electrocatalysts and thus their performances. DFT calculations showed that the intrinsic charge mobility of the pristine GDY monolayer (~2 × 105 cm2 V−1 s−1) is comparable with that of graphene (~3 × 105 cm2 V−1 s−1) [99], which highly facilitate the application of the GDY-based materials in electrocatalysis fields. The calculated band structures show that upon NiCo (Fig. 8 (a)) or FeCo dimer (S7(a)) anchoring, several flat bands are introduced near Ef. The calculated LDOS (Fig. S6) indicate that these flat bands come from the anchored Fe, Co, or Ni atoms. These localized impurity states near Ef not only could enhance the conductivity of GDY, but also induce localized spin magnetic moments (Table S4), which could play a role in the high catalytic activity of FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY. We have also further performed charge analysis along the reaction pathway to gain more insights into the excellent catalytic activity of FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY. According to previous studies [33,34], the catalysts with the adsorbed reaction intermediates have been divided into three moieties: the adsorbed N x H y species, the FeCoC8 or NiCoC8 unit consisting of the FeCo or NiCo dimer and their bonded eight carbon atoms, and the GDY substrate without FeCoC8 or NiCoC8 moiety. From Fig. 8(b), along the reaction pathway, except the second protonation step, the GDY substrate always serves as the donor, providing electrons to the adsorbed N x H y species and/or NiCoC8 unit. Similarly, from Fig. S7(b), except the last protonation step, the GDY substrate also always serves as the electron donor for FeCo@GDY. Therefore, the strong electron denoting ability of the GDY substrate should play an important part in the N2 capture and the subsequent protonation. We further studied the stability of FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY. For the kinetic stability, the CI-NEB calculations have been performed to search the minimum energy path for the dissociation of the FeCo dimer or NiCo dimer into two separated monomers on the GDY monolayer. As shown in Fig. 8(c) for NiCo@GDY, the energy barriers for the relocation of the NiCo dimer are as high as 2 eV (2.24 and 2.16 eV for two non-equivalent H1 sites), indicating that the dissociation of the embedded NiCo dimer and their further diffusion to form clusters could be hindered by the high kinetic barrier. Furthermore, AIMD simulations have been performed to explore the thermal stability of NiCo@GDY, with a time step of 2 ps at the temperature of 600 K. As shown in Fig. S8(a), the geometric structures of NiCo@GDY keep well within 8 ps. In addition, FeCo@GDY also exhibits high kinetic and thermal stabilities as shown in Figs. S7(c) and Fig. S8(b). Therefore, the FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY catalysts should have robust stability and durability to allow their long-term use. Finally, we would like to perform a preliminary study on the support effect on the atomic metal catalysts for NRR. We take N–doped graphene with the supported NiCo dimer (NiCo@NG) as an example for comparison with NiCo@GDY, the most active NRR catalyst predicted herein. NiCo@NG has been synthesized with the aid of metal–organic frameworks [104]. The geometrical model of the NiCo@NG catalyst, and the calculated free energy diagrams for both the alternating and distal pathways are shown in Fig. S9. As shown in Fig. S9, the PDS for NRR on NiCo@NG is the first protonation step, similar to the case of NiCo@GDY. However, the free energy uphill of this step for NiCo@NG (1.14 eV) is much higher than that for NiCo@GDY (0.36 eV), showing a strong support effect on the NRR catalytic activity of the supported metal dimer catalysts. The low activity of NiCo@NG should result from the insufficient activation of N2 molecule. The calculated adsorption energy for N2 on NiCo@NG is −0.62 eV with respect to the free N2 molecule, much higher than that (−0.90 eV) on NiCo@GDY. To understand different adsorption strength resulting from the support effect, we calculated charge transfer from the embedded NiCo dimer to the NG and GDY supports, There are 0.35 and 0.53 e electrons transferred from Ni and Co atoms for GDY support, respectively, much smaller than those for NG support (0.56 and 0.71 e electrons from Ni and Co atoms, respectively). Previous works [66] show that less electron transfer leads to higher activity of the Fe dimer on the different supports for CO2 and CO chemisorption. Therefore, herein the less electron transfer from NiCo dimer to GDY compared with NG plays an important role for the enhanced adsorption and activation of N2 molecule. Limited by the scope of the present study, we only present this preliminary investigation, and a systematical study will be performed in future. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, by means of DFT calculations combined with the CHE model, we have systematically studied the potential of the heteronuclear DACs FeM@ and NiM@GDY (M = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) as efficient NRR catalysts. Our theoretical results indicate that almost all these DACs can effectively bind and activate N2 molecule, and the different catalysts prefer different N2 adsorption configurations, which could be ascribed to the competition between the chemical bonding interaction and the structural distortion effect. Further, the FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY catalysts have strong N2 capture ability, weak NH3 binding strength, excellent NRR catalytic activity, high ability to suppress the competing HER, and good stability. The reaction pathways for both FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY prefer to the distal mechanisms with the calculated U Onset values of −0.44 and −0.36 V, respectively, which are comparable and even better than their homonuclear counterparts. Furthermore, FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY have higher ability to suppress HER than Fe2@ and Co2@GDY, which can be ascribed to the modulated d–band center by the cooperation of the heteronuclear atoms in the DACs. The present work not only proposes two efficient, low–cost, and stable atomic metal catalysts for NRR, but also provides a strategy, i.e., alloying the atomic metal catalysts, to improve the catalytic activity and/or selectivity of the NRR catalysts. Considering that there are large numbers of possible combinations of heteronuclear dimers, there might be some heteronuclear DACs exhibiting much better performance than FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY catalysts. In addition, our preliminary study on the support effect suggests that the catalyst support plays an important role for the performance of the atomic metal catalysts. We hope our studies could stimulate further theoretical and experimental works to explore the application of the heteronuclear atomic metal catalysts in NRR and many other important reactions. coredata.dc:description: Developing efficient electrocatalysts for nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is crucial to replace the both energy–intensive and environment–malignant Haber–Bosch process. Here using density functional theory calculations, we systematically studied the potential of the heteronuclear 3d transition metal dimers anchored graphdiyne monolayers (FeM@ and NiM@GDY, M = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) as efficient NRR catalysts. Among all the studied double–atom catalysts (DACs), FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY are the most promising with excellent NRR catalytic activity, high ability to suppress the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and good stability. For both FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY, NRR prefers to the distal pathway with the calculated onset potentials of −0.44 and −0.36 V, respectively, which are comparable and even better than their homonuclear counterparts. Moreover, FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY have higher ability to suppress HER than Fe2@ and Co2@GDY, which may result from the modulated d state electronic structure due to the synergy effect of the heteronuclear atoms in the DACs. Our work not only suggests that FeCo@ and NiCo@GDY hold great promises as efficient, low–cost, and stable DACs for NRR, but also further provides a strategy, i.e. alloying the atomic metal catalysts, to improve the NRR catalytic activity and/or selectivity.

coredata.dc:title: Theoretical screening of the transition metal heteronuclear dimer anchored graphdiyne for electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction
